personal-tech-experience.name: SUDS Hackathon Winners
personal-tech-experience.brief: Winners of the Stellenbosch Developer's Society 2025 Hackathon.

points.text: Dylan Swarts and I participated against 7 other teams in the SUDS Hackathon of 2025. The theme was to build something that would improve student life. Swarts and I (as a team called "Dylan Squared" since we are both called Dylan) developed a full-stack system called " Maroonut", a digitized version of the Stellenbosch University's Faculty yearbook. We built this system over a 38 period period from Friday, 3 October at 20:00 (Right after writing a 3rd year maths exam) to Sunday, 5 October at 10:00. The full implementation and detailed README can be found at Github via the link below.

points.name: Check out the website of my teammate, Dylan Swarts

points.caption: When you first arrive at maroonut, you will land on the home page, detailing the purpose and functionality of the service.

points.text: Maroonut uses React Router, so you can bookmark any page and share links to certain modules directly.

points.caption: You can log in to your own account, which allows you to view modules, post reviews on modules you've already completed, and even advertise yourself as a tutor for specific modules.

points.text: Note that user authentication was not fully implented as it was not the focus during our short timeframe, but future versions would likely authenticate via Stellenbosch's existing database.

points.caption: Once logged in, you can view all modules and even search for modules based on search terms to find what you're looking for.

Every module has a dedicated page with the module's framework, lecture and tutorial hours, and the module's pre- and corequistes, which also act as buttons to direct you to those modules. The module rating is based off of an average of all reviewer's ratings of the module.

Scrolling further down, you can view reviews for the module by people who have taken it in the past. This allows you to guage more about the module than a module framework allows, as you hear students' real world experience with the module to better advise you. If you've passed a module, you can give your own review on it, and rate it by clicking on the stars. Users can also gift and revoke 'acorns' to and from the review. Reviews are sorted descendingly by acorns so that the best reviews stay at the top.
You can also see users who are tutoring for the module, showing a brief description of each tutor's service and their rate, as well as buttons to contact them via email and visit their profiles.
On a user's profile page, you can see how many acorns they've been gifted over reviews, modules taken and their outcomes, and modules they've reviewed or are tutoring for.

personal-tech-experience.name: Standard Bank Hackathon
personal-tech-experience.brief: Performed behavioural segmentation on taxi drivers.

personal-tech-experience.name: Investec Tech Scholarship Mentorship
personal-tech-experience.brief: At the end of my first year I was awarded a full cost scholarship with Investec which has funded me since my second year. After my honours, I will then be able to go work for them. During the scholarship I have networked with many people at the company and have learned a lot about industry from them.

personal-tech-experience.name: Godot Game 'Collabyrinth'
personal-tech-experience.brief: I built a maze game in Godot 4. Check the README in the repo linked below.

points.text: Collabyrinth is a continuous passion-project that I incrementally develop to hone my skills in game-development before I tackle my first ambitious long-term project.

university-projects.name: Brainscraper [Fullstack Webdev]
university-projects.brief: A Kahoot-like online mutiplayer trivia game with websockets for real-time syncronization, full JWT + Refresh token Authentication, and some suspenseful music to keep the excitement going

university-projects.name: Ponderr [Fullstack Mobile Dev]
university-projects.brief: A tinder-style game used for a group of people to decide what to watch. Each player swipes on movies until all players agree. Players are authorized using Plex OAuth, and movie data is pulled from Plex.

university-projects.name: DFA + BPE LLM Tokenizer
university-projects.brief: An investigative-style project implementing a Tokenizer equivalent to that on minbpe's BasicTokenizer including optimizations, DFA visualtions, and more.

university-projects.name: Personal Website with Typescript and React
university-projects.brief: This is the website you're looking at now. Originally implemented in Javascript, it has since been adapted to typescript and improved in many ways.

university-projects.name: Othello Game Engine
university-projects.brief: Parallel search negamax algorithm in C using MPI.

university-projects.name: Networking Projects In Java
university-projects.brief: Chatroom, VoIP, file transfer and torrent.

university-projects.name: Machine Learning Algorithms
university-projects.brief: Various algorithms implemented in Jupyter with python, including Naive Bayes classifier, Logistic Regression, Principal Component Analysis, Linear Discriminant Analysis, The EM Algorithm, Gaussian Mixture Models, and Hidden Markov Models.

university-projects.name: LL(1) Compiler
university-projects.brief: Compiler implemented in C for a language called SIMPL. Included a scanner, parser, type-checking, and code generation.

university-projects.name: Air Race and Obstacle Chess Games
university-projects.brief: Games made in python, both with primative GUIs.

non-tech-endeavors.name: Transfer: The Severed System (My Novel)
non-tech-endeavors.brief: I have been working on a novel the past 8 years. I won a Gold Diploma for it in the Cape Town Writing Eisteddfod in 2021. I am working on publishing it. I have also written the first drafts for two sequels, and have plans for other works.

non-tech-endeavors.name: Reptile Park Volunteering
non-tech-endeavors.brief: I spent some time volunteering at the reptile garden in Stodels, Durbanville. Responsibilities included feeding reptiles, cleaning reptile tanks, sweeping, raking the sand in the rock monitor pits, and helping wherever else needed.

leadership-roles.name: Chairperson of Wildlife Society at Fairmont High
leadership-roles.brief: In this role, I organized events like guest speakers, cleanups, and excursions for the society. During this time I designed a logo for fabric bags that we sold to promote fabric bags over plastic. I also ran an ecobrick campaign where we as a society made and collected about 30 ecobricks that were donated to the cause.

leadership-roles.name: Chairperson of Media Appreciation Society at Fairmont High
leadership-roles.brief: My main endeavor in this role was to put together a video to promote the society. I was the society's first chairperson after it was born through the merging of multiple other societies, including the grapevine, a school magazine that I wrote for 4 times a year.

leadership-roles.name: Co-writer and Director of a One Act Play at Fairmont High
leadership-roles.brief: I co-wrote and directed a 20-minute comedy play called 'Erase and Rewind' about a man who goes back in time to have reverse-hand-dryers removed from his childhood school, to prevent his life from being ruined. During his adventure, he loses his time machine, which appears like a tv remote. Two children find it and cause chaos with it, like pausing time, changing the languages of their friends, and reversing time. We won a silver award for it at a ceremony called 'Silwervaring Kunstefees.'
